title: Why do I have a song stuck in my head that I really don't like? (Simply Irresistable - Robert Palmer) - Quora

response.answer_text: It is a catchy song, but otherwise I do not know. Often wonder if it’s triggered by some type of memory association when it happens to me with older songs like that. A few weeks ago, I could not get Leo Sayer’s When I Need You out of my head. I found myself singing and humming it under my breath. I was 7 when it came out. I do not own the song in any form, and do not recall hearing it recently. I don’t actively dislike the song, but I’m not a big Leo Sayer fan….it’s not something I would chose to listen to. Maybe something happened that day that took my brain back to 1976 and Leo Sayer subconsciously? Some odd associative connection. It’s just weird. But at least it fades pretty quick. I didn’t even recognize the song at first, just bits and pieces of it, so I sang the words and hummed the tune I remembered to my mom, who did know it. Actually seemed to help to listen to the song on youtube all the way through. Ear worm exorcised.

That happens to all of us. And I bet that it’s been happening since music first began being recorded. This happens to me, my friends, and my parents (and my grandparents also experienced it). As in your case, it can be a song that you don’t really like, or even some annoying commercial jingle. In my case, it’s usually a song that I like. As for “Simply Irresistible,” although I don’t mind it, my favourite Robert Palmer song is “Hyperactive.” It conjures up rather dark images for me, because of the way that it is featured in the 1987 film, “The Bedroom Window” (which is underrated, if you ask me). A serial killer is on the loose, and a rather drunk young woman is seen dancing in a very provocative manner to that song just before he murders her. And so, whenever I hear that song (which is on my iPod), I can’t help but think of that scene. If you want to get it out of your head, I suggest that you try playing another song. That might work.
